sen.j: 大将軍（だいしょうぐん、たいしょうぐん）
sen.e: Daishogun (also Taishogun)
Daishogun (also Taishogun)
Daishogun (also Taishogun)

sen.j: 中国の大将軍
sen.e: Daishogun in China
Daishogun in China
Daishogun in China

sen.j: 大将軍は、古代中国における各将軍の最上位者を意味する官職であり、古くは上将軍と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In ancient China, the Daishogun (Da jiang jun in Chinese) was a bureaucratic rank signifying the highest rank of all generals and was also called Jo-shogun (Sha jiang jun in Chinese).
sen.cmt: 上将軍: Jo-shogun (Sha jiang jun in Chinese)暫定訳
sen.e: In ancient China, the Daishogun (Da jiang jun in Chinese) was a bureaucratic rank signifying the highest rank of all generals and was also called Jo-shogun (Sha jiang jun in Chinese).
In ancient China, the Daishogun (Da jiang jun in Chinese) was a bureaucratic rank signifying the highest rank of all generals and was also called Jo-shogun (Sha jiang jun in Chinese).

sen.j: その起源は不明であるが、秦末の動乱期に、陳勝に背き、張耳と組んで武臣を趙王に擁立した陳余がこの名称を使用している。
sen.e: Although the origin is unknown, the title was used in the warring period of the late Qin Dynasty by Yo CHIN, who betrayed Sheng CHEN and worked with Er ZHANG to put a soldier on the throne as King Zhao.

Although the origin is unknown, the title was used in the warring period of the late Qin Dynasty by Yo CHIN, who betrayed Sheng CHEN and worked with Er ZHANG to put a soldier on the throne as King Zhao.

Although the origin is unknown, the title was used in the warring period of the late Qin Dynasty by Yo CHIN, who betrayed Sheng CHEN and worked with Er ZHANG to put a soldier on the throne as King Zhao.

sen.j: 前漢では当初非常置の職であったようで、楚漢戦争期の韓信以降は、匈奴が侵攻して来た際や反乱鎮圧に際してといった非常時に、臨時に政府要人が軍の総帥として任命されることが多かったようである。
sen.e: In the Former Han Dynasty, the post was initially used to fill emergency needs, with important government officials very often named as ad hoc chief of the army to quell riots and wars such as the Xiongno invasion, starting with Han Xin in the Chu-Han Contention period.

In the Former Han Dynasty, the post was initially used to fill emergency needs, with important government officials very often named as the ad hoc chief of the army to quell riots and wars such as the Xiongno invasion, starting with Han Xin in the Chu-Han Contention period.

In the Former Han Dynasty, the post was initially used to fill emergency needs, with important government officials very often named as the ad hoc chief of the army to quell riots and wars such as the Xiongno invasion, starting with Han Xin in the Chu-Han Contention period.

sen.j: 武帝 (漢)による積極的な対外政策が開始されると、常置の官職となった。
sen.e: The title became a permanent rank in the bureaucracy under Han Wudi (Han Dynasty), in his active external policy.
The title became a permanent rank in the bureaucracy under Han Wudi (Han Dynasty), in his active external policy.
The title became a permanent rank in the bureaucracy under Han Wudi (Han Dynasty), in his active external policy.

sen.j: この時期の大将軍として、対匈奴戦争で大きな功績を挙げた衛青が知られる。
sen.e: A well-known Daishogun during the period is Wei Qing, who was highly successful in the campaigns against the Xiongnu tribes.
A well-known Daishogun during the period is Wei Qing, who was highly successful in the campaigns against the Xiongnu tribes.
A well-known Daishogun during the period is Wei Qing, who was highly successful in the campaigns against the Xiongnu tribes.

sen.j: 武帝没後、外戚の権力が強まり、政治に参与するようになると、外戚勢力のリーダーがこの職に任ぜられ、政権を握ることが多くなった。
sen.e: After Wudi's death, the strength of the maternal side of the imperial family grew and began to intervene in politics, leading to the leader of such forces being frequently given the title along with political power.

After Wudi's death, the strength of the maternal side of the imperial family grew and began to intervene in politics, where the leader of such forces was frequently given the title along with political power.

After Wudi's death, the strength of the maternal side of the imperial family grew and began to intervene in politics, where the leader of such forces was frequently given the title along with political power.

sen.j: この傾向は、後漢に入ってからも初期の3代の皇帝（光武帝、明帝 (漢)、章帝 (漢)）の時代を除いて続行し、彼等外戚集団と宦官との政権争いが後漢の政治において大きな位置を占めるようになり、結果として後漢滅亡の要因となった。
sen.e: This continued into the Later Han Dynasty, except during the reigns of the first three emperors (Guangwu, Ming Di and Zhang (Han Dynasty)), with clashes over political control between forces representing the material side of the Imperial family and the bureaucrats becoming a major factor in Later Han politics and eventually leading to the dynasty's downfall.

This continued into the Later Han Dynasty, except during the reigns of the first three emperors (Guangwu, Ming Di, and Zhang or Han Dynasty), with clashes over political control between forces representing the material side of the Imperial family and the bureaucrats becoming a major factor in Later Han politics and eventually leading to the dynasty's downfall.

This continued into the Later Han Dynasty, except during the reigns of the first three emperors (Guangwu, Ming Di, and Zhang or Han Dynasty), with clashes over political control between forces representing the maternal side of the Imperial family and the bureaucrats becoming a major factor in Later Han politics and eventually leading to the dynasty's downfall.

sen.j: 三国時代 (中国)以降も大将軍の職は存在したが、その権力は徐々に弱められることとなり、名誉職としての色合いが強まっていった。
sen.e: The title of Daishogun remained in the Three Kingdoms Period of Chinese history but with declining power and evolving into a post of honorary nature.
The title of Daishogun remained during the Three Kingdoms Period of Chinese history, but with declining power and it evolved into a post of honorary nature.
The title of Daishogun remained during the Three Kingdoms Period of Chinese history, but with declining power and it evolved into a post of honorary nature.

sen.j: 日本の大将軍
sen.e: Daishogun in Japan
Daishogun in Japan
Daishogun in Japan

sen.j: 日本では平安時代、征討軍を編成するにあたり、三人以上の将軍を任ずる場合にその主将を大将軍として任じた。
sen.e: In Japan, the title Daishogun was used to designate the top commander to lead a "seitogun" (expeditionary force), when there were more than 3 generals.
In Japan, the title Daishogun was used to designate the top commander to lead a "seitogun" (expeditionary force), when there were more than three generals.
In Japan, the title Daishogun was used to designate the top commander to lead a "seitogun" (expeditionary force), when there were more than three generals.

sen.j: または、三位以上の公卿を将軍とする際も軍職の名を大将軍と号することもあった。
sen.e: It was also used as a military title when a Court noble of Sanmi Rank (Third Rank) or higher.
It was also used as a military title when a Court noble of Sanmi Rank (Third Rank) or higher.
It was also used as a military title when a Court noble of Sanmi Rank (Third Rank) or higher.

sen.j: 後に広く武将を指す語ともなり、平安時代から鎌倉時代初期にかけては官職ではなく私称として用いる場合も散見された。
sen.e: It later became a word referring to military commanders in general and was used as an unofficial title rather than a bureaucratic rank in some instances in the Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

It later became a word referring to military commanders in general and was used as an unofficial title rather than a bureaucratic rank in some instances during the Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

It later became a word referring to military commanders in general and was used as an unofficial title rather than a bureaucratic rank in some instances during the Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

sen.j: 平家物語では熊谷直実が源平合戦における平家方の武将である平敦盛を指して大将軍と呼んでいるなど、身分の高い武将を指す語として用いられた例も見受けられる。
sen.e: There are also instances of the title being used to refer to a military leader of high rank, such as the reference in "Heike Monogatari" (The Tale of the Heike) by Naozane KUMAGAI of TAIRA no Atsumori of the Heike clan as Daishogun in the Genpei War.

There are also instances of the title being used to refer to a military leader of high rank, such as the reference in "Heike Monogatari" (The Tale of the Heike) by Naozane KUMAGAI of TAIRA no Atsumori of the Heike clan as Daishogun in the Genpei War.

There are also instances of the title being used to refer to a military leader of high rank, such as the reference in "Heike Monogatari" (The Tale of the Heike) by Naozane KUMAGAI of TAIRA no Atsumori of the Heike clan as Daishogun in the Genpei War.

sen.j: また、承久の乱の際に京都に進撃する鎌倉幕府軍の諸将をそれぞれ東山道大将軍、北陸道大将軍などと称した例や、南北朝時代 (日本)に北畠顕家が鎮守大将軍（鎮守府将軍）に任ぜられた例もある。
sen.e: In the Jokyu War, the military leaders of the Kamakura shogunate forces attacking Kyoto were given titles such as Daishogun of Tozan-do Road and Daishogun of Hokuriku-do Road, and Akiie KITABATAKE was appointed Chinju taishogun (Chinju-fu shogun) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

In the Jokyu War, the military leaders of the Kamakura shogunate forces attacking Kyoto were given titles such as Daishogun of Tozan-do Road and Daishogun of Hokuriku-do Road, and Akiie KITABATAKE was appointed Chinju taishogun (Chinju-fu shogun) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

In the Jokyu War, the military leaders of the Kamakura shogunate forces attacking Kyoto were given titles such as Daishogun of Tozan-do Road and Daishogun of Hokuriku-do Road, and Akiie KITABATAKE was appointed Chinju taishogun (Chinju-fu shogun) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

sen.j: しかし、将軍ないし大将軍という場合には幕府の主宰者を指す性格が強くなり、征夷大将軍以外の用例としては次第に使われなくなった。
sen.e: However, the titles shogun and daishogun were used more increasingly to refer to the head of the shogunate and were used is declining frequency, except in the case of "seii taishogun."
However, the titles shogun and daishogun were used more increasingly to refer to the head of the shogunate and were used is declining frequency, except in the case of "seii taishogun."
However, the titles shogun and daishogun were used more increasingly to refer to the head of the shogunate and were used is declining frequency, except in the case of "seii taishogun."

sen.j: 江戸時代末期に征討大将軍が任じられているが、一般化するには至らずに終わっている。
sen.e: A seito daishogun (the general temporarily appointed for overthrowing the shogunate in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi) was appointed in the late Edo period but never grew in usage.
A seito daishogun (the general temporarily appointed for overthrowing the shogunate in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi) was appointed during the late Edo period but it never grew in usage.
A seito daishogun (the general temporarily appointed for overthrowing the shogunate in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi) was appointed during the late Edo period but it never grew in usage.

sen.j: 陰陽道の大将軍
sen.e: Daishogun in Onmyodo
Daishogun in Onmyodo
Daishogun in Onmyodo

sen.j: 陰陽道では、大将軍は八将神の第2であり、太白（金星）の精である。
sen.e: In Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements), the Daishogun is the second of the Hasshojin (Eight General Gods) and the western god in the Yin-Yang doctrine.

In Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements), the Daishogun is the second of the Hasshojin (Eight General Gods) and the western god in the Yin-Yang doctrine.

In Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements), the Daishogun is the second of the Hasshojin (Eight General Gods) and the western god in the Yin-Yang doctrine.

sen.j: 魔王天王、方伯神ともいう。
sen.e: It is also called Mao Tenno and Hohakushin (one of the eight gods).
It is also called Mao Tenno and Hohakushin (one of the eight gods).
It is also called Mao Tenno and Hohakushin (one of the eight gods).
